title: What's the best digital piano model for an amateur player who wants weighted action and 88 keys? - Quora

response.answer_text: There must be around a hundred different weighted action 88-key electronic keyboard / digital pianos that would probably meet your needs. From the answers, you’ll find everyone has different reasons / skills / prices / etc. for the ones they like best. For me, my preferences are for: Casio Privia PX-160BK (about $400)Yamaha P45/P71 (about $400)Yamaha P115 (about $500)Roland FP-30 (about $600)Here’s a short run-down on each for why: Casio PX-160BK Great price for a weighted 88-key digital pianoSpeakers sound excellent (2 at 8W), with front / rear soundingKeyboard feel / action with 3 sensitivity levelsLots of digital effects and recording capabilitiesYamaha P45/P71 Excellent priceGraded hammer key weighting is realisticAcoustics are nice, speakers have good output (2 at 6W)Voices, sampling and mixing can do a lotYamaha P115 Costs a little more, but you get a bunch more features than P45/P71USB / MIDI port nice for external connection & storing musicRoland Probably one of the best keyboard actionsThere’s a dual mode for teacher / student playing which is great for learningIf you’ve gotten this far, then you might be interested in more details on each of these, and you can check out this review: Best 88-Key Portable Electronic Piano Thanks again Kevin McCullough for asking my thoughts on this. Leave some comments on which digital pianos you decide are best for you…

All things considered, I say the PX-5s Casio. You see them more and more with real gigging players. At 25 pounds, it is a new paradigm of plastic. I bought it because the action and the texture of the keys feels more like a piano than literally anything else available. I wanted something light weight. a 50 pound Kurzweil with case is heavy and doesn't fit in many cars. For reference, I sold pianos for a year for a store with hundreds. I played the 9 foot grands, the German makes. Yamaha, etc. And hundreds of old junkers. I played all the electric Yamahas (and accoustic) and I disagree with anyone who thinks Yamaha keyboards have the best action. I don't think anyone tries to say the have the best piano sounds. It actually can do more than people realize, with hexlayers. You can program your own sounds or buy them or share for free on Casio forum. For the cost, about $900 US, it is my first choice for a stage piano that I have to carry and setup. Hell, I can load any software synth or apps in my mini iPad, route it back into they PX-5s, and you realize… you just bought the best piano midi controller too. Why buy the one that sounds best when you can use any keyboard as a midi controller and sounds are cheap now. I also quickly realized, their piano sounds better than any of the others, imo. I have owned kurzweils, Rolands, korgs.
